Many farmers and ranchers have benefited from the oil boom, some are even getting rich.

We're on a ranch in western North Dakota, where a blue tractor is lifting a big, round bale of hay.

He says oil booms come with the territory, but usually they're not this intense.
Oh yeah, this is a completely different animal than we've seen before.

Farmers learned of another downside to the oil boom this past harvest season: When space on railroads was at a premium.

Marilyn Hudson has lived most of her 77 years in Parshall, North Dakota, on the Fort Berthold Indian Reservation.
